title: Saffron Trail Walking Route

images.title: John Allan / Southend Pier
images.caption: Southend Pier. Built in 1830, Southend Pier is the longest pleasure pier in the world, stretching 1.3 miles out from the shore. The 72 mile trail starts from here. The trail's name references the cultivation of crocuses in the Saffron Walden area from which the spice saffron is obtained.

images.title: Trevor Harris / Autumn in Hadleigh Castle Country Park
images.caption: Autumn in Hadleigh Castle Country Park

images.title: Janine Forbes / Walden Castle, Saffron walden
images.caption: Walden Castle, Saffron walden. Walden Castle, Saffron Walden. Built sometime between 1125 and 1141 little remains today except the flint walls of the keep.

images.title: Following the Saffron Trail on seafront at Westcliff by Chris Morgan, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Following the Saffron Trail on the seafront at Westcliff

description: A walk through the Essex countryside from the coast at Southend-on-Sea to Saffron Walden. The walk starts by the pier at Southend and follows the coast to the lovely Hadleigh Country Park. The 400 acre park includes the ruins of the 13th century Hadleigh Castle,  mixed woodland, meadows and marshland. From the park you then head north to Chelmsford, passing Hockley Woods, Rayleigh and Danbury with a waterside stretch along the River Crouch at South Woodham Ferrers. At Chelmsford you'll enjoy a walk along the River Cam before continuing north to Great Dunmow and Newport before finishing at Saffron Walden.
